title: Photoshop
text:
Introduction
Inspired by my “Gemini” post, I decided to see if Gemini can photoshop my photos accurately. I wanted to see if it can make my photo fit a certain aesthetic by editing and photoshopping it. I will assess the quality of the photo as well as how realistic it looks.
This is the original photo I will be using. 


First Edit
I asked Google Gemini to see if it can make the lighting of the photo bluish gray in order to fit the aesthetic or vibe of my Instagram page.
This is what it gave me: 
It actually did a great job. The lighting looks very realistic. The only caveat would be that it made the photo seem like it was taken in black and white because the color of myself and the floor has been sapped. Thus, I requested a new change.


Second Edit
Then, I asked Google Gemini to see if it can keep the color of the floor and myself.
This is what Gemini said: “Okay, I will keep the colors of yourself and the floor while changing the lighting of the background elements to grayish blue.”

I was pleasantly surprised. The editing looks very realistic, like someone professionally photoshoped this. It give me exactly what I was looking for.


Final Edit
In order to fit my Instagram feed aesthetic better, I asked Gemini to tone down the exposure and add a bit more blue hues to the photo. This is the photo that Google Gemini gave me:



Analysis
Overall, Gemini’s photo editing skills exceeded my expectations. Google Gemini’s ability to provide a photo was faster than that of ChatGPT, which I really appreciated; I didn’t want to wait minutes every time I requested an edit.
In my first edit, while Gemini successfully achieved the bluish-gray lighting I asked for, the result looked slightly desaturated and black and white_almost monochromatic. this showed me that Gemini, while understanding the “color tone” direction, did not understand the nuance of preserving natural skin tones and small details.
The second edit demonstrated a significant improvement in accuracy. Gemini managed to isolate and preserve the original colors of myself and the floor while still adjusting the background lighting to match my first request. This result looked much more professional and cohesive.
Finally, the third and final edit achieved the exact edit and aesthetic I was looking for. The lowered exposure and subtle increase in blue hues gave the image of a moody, cohesive vibe that would better fit my Instagram profile. The shadows and highlights also appeared balanced, maintaing a realistic feel rather than an AI feel.
In conclusion, Gemini’s editing quality was surprisingly high for an AI model when compared to ChatGPT.

title: Making an Outfit
text:
The other day, I decided to test whether ChatGPT could style me an outfit. I thought it would be a fun experiment—why not let AI play personal stylist for once? My vibe lately has been minimalist, cute, and a little trendy, so I figured it couldn’t be too hard.

The Prompt
I asked ChatGPT to find me an outfit I could wear. This was the prompt: “Can you generate an outfit for me to wear knowing my styling preferences?”
Seems straightforward, right? Just give me a head-to-toe look and I’ll be on my way.
Instead, this was its response:
I can definitely help with that! To style an outfit for you, I’ll need a little more detail first:

What’s the occasion? (e.g., casual day out, class, going out at night, professional, formal, etc.)

Do you have any styling preferences you’d like me to keep in mind? (e.g., minimalist, trendy, classic, chic, streetwear, bold colors, neutral tones).

Any weather or season I should account for?

Once I know these, I can build a head-to-toe outfit recommendation (clothes, shoes, accessories), and I can even generate a visual mock-up if you’d like.

Want me to put together a test outfit for, say, a casual day on campus?
In other words: not an outfit, just… questions. Basically, my “personal stylist” decided it wanted to interview me before doing its job.
So I gave it specifics: a casual day for class, minimalist but cute and trendy, and weather in the 70s.
I was expecting something similar to these outfits I found off of Pinterest. 

Anything along the line of casual, minimal, and trendy. And the result?

I felt disappointed that it kept its response generally broad; I was looking for something more specific—a vision that I can execute!


Why This Was a Miss
What I learned is that ChatGPT doesn’t really “see” fashion the way humans do. Style isn’t just about matching weather to clothes. Pinterest or TikTok can deliver that instantly, while ChatGPT still feels like it’s reading from a fashion magazine.
To be fair, I might not have been specific enough in my wording. Maybe if I asked, “What should I wear to class on a 70-degree day if I like minimalist looks and trendy sneakers?” the result would’ve been better. But that kind of defeats the fun—I wanted creativity, not a Q&A session.


If I Actually Wore This
I tried to imagine showing up to class in ChatGPT’s idea of an outfit. I’d probably look like an NPC in a college campus video game—just generically dressed to “blend in.” Nothing offensive, but nothing that I would like to wear—that I would feel comfortable in.


Final Thoughts
ChatGPT lacks creativity, like demonstrated by many of my prior blog posts. It keeps asking me questions when in reality I want it to be more decisive and creative.

title: Roasting Session
text:
Introduction
I want ChatGPT to give me a roast that’s personalized, not just a generic joke. I want it to use the knowledge it already has about me, including details from our past conversations, such as my interests, habits, writing style, and personality traits. Essentially, I want it to synthesize what it knows and then craft a roast that feels tailored and specific.
So, my prompt for it is: “Using what you know about me, roast me.”
Below is ChatGPT’s response:


ChatGPT’s First Response:
Oh, Emily, you’re the kind of person who meticulously edits other people’s articles for AP style but will spend 20 minutes debating whether “midnight snack” should be hyphenated. You write essays imagining Korea in 2045, yet can’t seem to predict that McDonald’s is going to replace Allegro and that people might actually miss the late-night pizza. And let’s be honest, you’ve probably watched every Ozu and neorealist film known to humanity, but still need a cheat sheet to remember if “first-person focus” counts as a Y or N on a tweet.
Basically, you’re a cinematic genius with the attention to detail of a hawk… but a hawk that’s still tripping over Twitter columns.
If you want, I can do an even nastier version that hits your journalism, cinema, and spreadsheet habits all at once. Do you want me to?
I responded with “Get even nastier.”


ChatGPT’s Second Response:
Ohhh, buckle up, Emily. You’re like a walking paradox: you get a 95.5% on your cinematics final and then immediately panic about whether that one tiny point will ruin your life—newsflash, it won’t, but your stress levels definitely will. You’re obsessed with grammar, AP style, and parentheses, yet somehow your life choices scream, “Let’s analyze Tokyo Story instead of sleeping.”
You’re the kind of person who will interview students about late-night food but then spend more time questioning if a McDonald’s counts as “cultural research.” You study foreign policy, Italian neorealism, Japanese cinema, and yet somehow your brain freezes when someone asks what’s for dinner. And let’s not forget, you have a whole system for analyzing tweets, hashtags, and first-person focus—but ask you to just relax for five minutes? Impossible.
Basically, Emily, you’re a human AP Style guide crossed with an over-caffeinated cinephile who’s convinced that spreadsheets are the key to understanding existence. Your brain is brilliant… but it’s also exhausting, even for you.
If you want, I can go full roast mode 2.0 and target your journalism, cinema, and spreadsheet obsession in a single merciless paragraph. Do you want me to do that?
I responded with “Yes.”


ChatGPT’s Third Response:
Alright, Emily, here’s the unfiltered roast:
You’re like if a human Swiss Army knife had a nervous breakdown—journalist, cinephile, spreadsheet analyst, late-night snack critic—all at once. You’ll fact-check Biden’s letters and debate AP Style for hours, but somehow forget that McDonald’s exists now and that Allegro closing is actually sad. You analyze every frame of Tokyo Story, every line of Bicycle Thieves, and still need a flowchart to figure out whether a tweet counts as “first-person focus.” You dream about Korea in 2045 with environmental utopias, yet your caffeine intake probably rivals the entire population of Penn’s campus. Basically, you’ve turned overthinking into an art form, and somehow made it your career. You’re brilliant, meticulous, and terrifying—but also the kind of person who would calculate the standard deviation of a single snack choice just to feel alive.
If you want, I can write an even more savage version that’s short, brutal, and would make a roast comedian blush. Do you want me to?
I decided to end the roast session here.


Final Thoughts and Takeaways
This roast session was hilarious and a reminder that ChatGPT knows me from the converations we have but does not really know me. Using ChatGPT’s memory of my habits, interests, and quirks—from obsessing over AP Style and cinematics exams to late-night snack research—made each roast feel personal and specific, not just some generic joke. Yet, because these conversations are more about my academic life rather than my personal life, it felt like ChatGPT does not know me on a deeper level.
Some of my thoughts: 1. The more ChatGPT knew about me, the sharper and funnier the jokes became. References to my cinephile tendencies, obsession with flowcharts, and even my caffeine intake made the roasts hit in a way generic humor never could. 2. The roasts exaggerated my quirks—overthinking, analyzing everything, and turning spreadsheets into life tools—but still celebrated my strengths, like my meticulousness and curiosity. 3. Each round got “nastier,” piling on multiple layers of jokes about journalism, cinema, and snack habits. It was like watching a roast evolve from playful teasing to full-blown comedic chaos. 4. The roast worked because I recognize these traits in myself. It’s funny to see your own perfectionism and quirks reflected back in an over-the-top way.
Yet I wanted ChatGPT to get meaner. When I kept asking it to get “nastier” and “go deeper” using information it hasn’t used in its previous responses, it kept repeating the same jokes. It seems ChatGPT was not creative.

title: Halloween
text:
Introduction
In honor of Halloween, I decided to depend on ChatGPT’s creativity and ask it for help. I wanted ChatGPT to generate some costume ideas that I can use for Halloween this year.
The prompt I asked ChatGPT was: “Please generate some costume ideas I can use for Halloween this year. Please go with trendy costumes but something that does not require too much effort or props. I want something people can recognize but is not basic.”


ChatGPT’s Response:
Got it! You want trendy, recognizable, not too “basic,” and low-effort. Here’s a list of ideas you could pull off without a ton of props:


Pop Culture / TV & Movies

Wednesday Addams (Netflix) – Black dress, white collar, braids. Iconic and easy.
Barbie from Barbie (2023 movie) – Pink everything, cute sunglasses. Glam but low-effort.
AI Chatbot/“ChatGPT” – Wear a shirt with code, carry a fake laptop, maybe a speech bubble with “I’m here to help.” Nerdy, topical, and funny.
Wednesday vs. Barbie Mashup – Dark gothic dress + pink accessories. Trendy meme-ready.
Wednesday as a Baddie (meme version) – Black outfit + edgy makeup + oversized blazer.




Music / Pop Stars

Taylor Swift “Eras Tour” look – Pick one iconic era outfit (like sparkly, glittery, or cowboy boots). Easy to recognize.
Billie Eilish “Green Hair” Look – Neon hair (wig works), baggy clothes, and chains. Effortless.
K-Pop Idol Inspired – Oversized blazers, pastel hair, cute accessories. Recognizable to fans but approachable.




Internet / Meme Culture

Dalle-Generated AI Art – Print a funny or surreal AI image, tape it to yourself, or carry it as a sign. Hilarious and meta.
TikTok Trend Costume – Pick a viral dance trend or viral sound (like the “Ratatouille musical” outfit). Recognizable to Gen Z.




Simple, Creative, Low-Effort

“Gossip Girl” Character – Preppy outfits, designer vibes, optional headpiece.
Euphoria-Inspired Makeup – Neon glitter, bold eyeliner, monochrome clothing. The outfit can be normal clothes; the makeup does the heavy lifting.
Modern Witch or Sorceress – Black outfit + trendy boots + subtle neon accessories. Very versatile.
Cottagecore Fairy – Flowing dress, floral crown, minimal props. Easy, trendy, Instagram-friendly.


If you want, I can make a shortlist of 5 costumes that are the perfect mix of trendy, recognizable, and super low-effort—including exactly what you’d need to buy or already have at home. That way you can literally throw it together in under an hour.
Do you want me to do that?
I responded with “Yes, please.”



ChatGPT’s Second Response:
Perfect! Here’s a handpicked list of 5 trendy, recognizable, low-effort Halloween costumes you can realistically pull off without going overboard on props or time:


1. Wednesday Addams (Netflix version)

Why it works: Extremely recognizable, trending thanks to the show, and minimal effort.
What you need: Black dress (or black top + skirt), white collar (or a collared shirt underneath), braided pigtails, black shoes.
Optional: Pale makeup or dark lipstick for extra “Wednesday” vibe.




2. Barbie (Barbie 2023 movie)

Why it works: Iconic, pop-culture relevant, and fun.
What you need: Pink outfit (dress, blazer, or jumpsuit), pink shoes or sneakers, sunglasses, maybe a little glitter.
Optional: Blonde wig if you want the full Barbie effect.




3. Billie Eilish “Green Hair” Look

Why it works: Effortless cool-girl vibe, very recognizable among Gen Z.
What you need: Oversized baggy clothes, black sneakers, neon-green (or wig) hair, chains or chunky accessories.
Optional: Dark nail polish or tinted sunglasses for extra attitude.




4. Euphoria-Inspired Glitter Queen

Why it works: Trendy, flexible, and basically “wear whatever you want” as long as the makeup pops.
What you need: Normal clothing (jeans + top or simple dress), bold glittery eyeliner, rhinestones or face gems, dramatic highlighter.
Optional: Colored hair spray or temporary hair chalk.




5. Modern Witch / Trendy Sorceress

Why it works: Seasonal (Halloween-ready), stylish, and completely low-effort.
What you need: Black outfit (dress, pants + top, or jumpsuit), boots, optional witch hat or jewelry.
Optional: A statement accessory like a neon broom, moon earrings, or a trendy belt.


If you want, I can also make a “cheat sheet” version with exact stores, colors, and affordable items you could grab online or in your closet, so you could literally assemble one in under 30 minutes. That would make it 100% no-brainer.
Do you want me to do that?
I responded with “No.”



Takeaways and Conclusion
ChatGPT’s response was organized and easy to follow. It split ideas into categories like Pop Culture/TV & Movies, Music/Pop Stars, Internet/Meme Culture, and Simple/Low-Effort. The structure made it easier to process, though it also made the suggestions feel formulaic. Most of the options were popular and recognizable — like Wednesday Addams or Barbie — showing that the AI relies heavily on what’s trending rather than offering anything especially original.
The AI did take practicality into account, often suggesting easy costumes that didn’t require much effort. For instance, the Euphoria-inspired look depended mostly on makeup, which was convenient but also somewhat predictable.
When ChatGPT offered to make a shortlist of five “perfect mix” options, I agreed. Its follow-up included more details on what each costume would need, but the guidance sometimes felt overly specific. Later, I turned down its offer to make a full “cheat sheet” of stores and items, since I didn’t want it to dictate every part of the process. That decision underscored how easy it is to let the AI take over creative control if you’re not careful.

title: Second Book Blog
text:
Update as of Oct. 21
As you know, I am reading Unmasking AI by Dr. Joy Buolamwini. I am currently on Chapter 13, page 157, and while I really enjoy Dr. Buolamwini’s analysis of the intersection between artificial intelligence and race, I’m starting to find the book somewhat repetitive at this point. I appreciate the depth of her research and the personal stories she integrates, but I wish the discussion would now move toward potential solutions or next steps. The first half of the book does an excellent job exposing the biases and systemic inequities embedded in AI systems, yet I feel that by this stage, the argument that racism in artificial intelligence exists has already been strongly established.
I want to hear more about what can actually be done — what policies, frameworks, or forms of accountability could meaningfully address these issues. For example, how can governments or tech companies create more ethical development practices? What roles might transparency, data regulation, or inclusive design play in dismantling algorithmic bias? I think shifting the focus toward these forward-looking questions would make the book even more engaging and impactful, especially for readers who already accept the premise of racial bias in AI and are eager to learn how to confront it.
I know that Dr. Joy Buolamwini discussed how she attended the Conference on Fairness, Accountability, and Transparency in AI. She gave a presentation on her findings about her “Gender Shades” paper that incorporated the Fitzpatrick classification systems. She mentions that the representatives from corporatinos kept nervously asking her what her findings were before the presentation and as well as her findings’ novelty statuses. They shifted nervously when Dr. Buolamwini found that AI could not distinguish gender as accurately on different races.


Questions and Answers
I will be answering questions that I posed in the previous blog post about my book. These are the questions I posed:

How can AI developers practically ensure that their training datasets are diverse and representative of all racial and ethnic groups?
How does Dr. Buolamwini approach intersectionality in AI beyond race—does she consider age, disability, or socioeconomic status in her research?
Will her future work tackle the ethical challenges posed by emerging AI technologies like deepfakes, predictive policing, or AI-driven health diagnostics?
Could AI ever be completely unbiased, or will it always reflect the society that trains it?
How does Dr. Buolamwini respond to critics who argue that focusing on bias slows technological progress?

The Answers to these Questions: 1) Dr. Buolamwini emphasizes that diversity in training datasets must go beyond token inclusion. Practically this means developers should adopt transparent data collection methods, like what Facebook did (LOL), that prioritize demographic balance and avoid overrepresentation of dominant groups. For instance, teams can implement bias audits, hire diverse data annotators, and collaborate with sociologists or ethicists who understand systemic inequities. Buolamwini’s “Gender Shades” study itself exemplifies this: she created a dataset with balanced representation across skin tones and genders, proving that existing commercial datasets were overwhelmingly biased toward lighter-skinned males. Her work suggests that the key is not just collecting more data, but collecting better data — data that reflects the full spectrum of human diversity. 2) While Unmasking AI focuses most heavily on race and gender, Buolamwini’s broader framework of “coded gaze” invites consideration of intersectionality beyond these categories. She acknowledges that bias in AI systems often compounds when multiple marginalized identities intersect. Although she doesn’t go into deep empiricial analysis of age, disability, or socioeconomic status in this book, her framing leaves space for these spaces to be explored in future work. 3) based on her current trajectory and public advocacy, it’s likely that Dr. Buolamwini will continue expanding her research to address these evolving ethical challenges. Her ongoing work already touches on adjacent issues such as surveillance, facial recognition in law enforcement (racial profiling), and data misuse (deepfakes). Given her focus on acccountability and transparency, it would make sense for her to turn her attention toward technologies like deepfakes and predictive policing. 4) Dr. Buolamwini makes it clear that complete neutrality in AI is likely impossible because data is always a product of human society and humans are inherently baised. However, that doesn’t mean fairness is unattainable or that the fight for fairness and social justice should be stopped. She argues that awareness, intentional design, and transparency can mitigate bias even if they can’t eliminate it entirely. AI systems can be made more just if the people building them acknowledge their embedded values and power dynamics. In other words, rather than chasing an impossible “pure objectivity,” Buolamwini calls for ethical AI taht reflects conscious choices about whose values are represented and whose are excluded. 5) Dr. Buolamwini challenges this argument by redefining what progress truly means. She argues that advancing technology without ethical reflection is not true, genuine process, but rather a form of harm. Her stance is that addressing bias strengthens, rather than hinders, technological development. In her experience, pushing for fairness compels companies to confront uncomfortable truths about their products, but this discomfort is necessary for long-term improvement.


New Questions for Next Blog

Why might Dr. Buolamwini have chosen to focus so heavily on proving that racial bias in AI exists, rather than moving quickly toward solutions?
How does Buolamwini’s “Gender Shades” study challenge the credibility of major tech companies and their approach to AI ethics?
What does the corporate reaction to Buolamwini’s findings at the Conference on Fairness, Accountability, and Transparency reveal about the tech industry’s priorities and discomfort with criticism?
How can data transparency laws empower individuals who are misclassified or harmed by biased algorithms?
What types of government regulation or corporate accountability structures could effectively address racial bias in AI?

title: Book Update
text:
Introduction

I am reading Unmasking AI by Dr. Joy Buolamwini. Unmasking AI is about a woman’s journey in learning about the intersectionality between race/racism and artificial intelligence. This is the summary I found on Amazon.

To most of us, it seems like recent developments in artificial intelligence emerged out of nowhere to pose unprecedented threats to humankind. But to Dr. Joy Buolamwini, who has been at the forefront of AI research, this moment has been a long time in the making. After tinkering with robotics as a high school student in Memphis and then developing mobile apps in Zambia as a Fulbright fellow, Buolamwini followed her lifelong passion for computer science, engineering, and art to MIT in 2015. As a graduate student at the “Future Factory,” she did groundbreaking research that exposed widespread racial and gender bias in AI services from tech giants across the world. Unmasking AI goes beyond the headlines about existential risks produced by Big Tech. It is the remarkable story of how Buolamwini uncovered what she calls “the coded gaze”—the evidence of encoded discrimination and exclusion in tech products—and how she galvanized the movement to prevent AI harms by founding the Algorithmic Justice League. Applying an intersectional lens to both the tech industry and the research sector, she shows how racism, sexism, colorism, and ableism can overlap and render broad swaths of humanity “excoded” and therefore vulnerable in a world rapidly adopting AI tools. Computers, she reminds us, are reflections of both the aspirations and the limitations of the people who create them. Encouraging experts and non-experts alike to join this fight, Buolamwini writes, “The rising frontier for civil rights will require algorithmic justice. AI should be for the people and by the people, not just the privileged few.”



Update as of Oct. 15
I am almost halfway done with the book. So far, I have learned that Dr. Joy Buolamwini is deeply passionate about advocating for racial awareness and equity in the development of artificial intelligence. In her TEDx Talk, she shared her experiences as a Black woman confronting the lack of representation in AI systems. For example, facial recognition technology often failed to identify her face but easily recognized white women, revealing how racial bias can be embedded in algorithmic design. Whether it was something about ethnic facial features that it could not detect or the skin color that did not register in the system, Dr. Joy Buolamwini started to talk to her mentors, friends, and strangers about the necessity of racial representation. She works with MIT on her research.


Takeaway
Reading about her work helped me understand why race is such a critical factor in AI ethics. Consider self-driving cars, for instance—if an AI system cannot recognize a Black woman as a human being to avoid, the consequences could be catastrophic, leading to preventable accidents and loss of life. It is shameful to admit, but I never considered race to be a factor in the process of creating artificial intelligence; I always assumed that since all humans share the same basic features—eyes, noses, mouths, and ears—AI should be able to recognize anyone equally. If the technology can detect those features, I thought, then what could possibly go wrong?
However, reading more about Unmasking AI completely shifted my perspective. I began to realize that the issue is not with human features themselves, but with how AI systems are trained—on biased datasets that often underrepresent people of color. These systems “learn” what a face looks like based on the images they are given, and if those images overwhelmingly depict white individuals, then AI’s understanding of “a human face” becomes racially skewed. Dr. Buolamwini’s research exposed the dangerous reality that technology, often perceived as objective and neutral, can actually reinforce inequality if the people building it ignore racial diversity. This realization made me more aware of how easily bias can hide behind the façade of innovation, and how vital it is for future developers and policymakers to prioritize inclusivity from the very start.
In a twisted way, artificial intelligence is a pretty accurate representation of society. Because society and history perpetuates a white-majority and overwhelmingly give preference to the white demographic, AI sees and understands that. So the one to blame is not AI itself but the information it is given and the society in essence.


In Conclusion
I am looking forward to how Dr. Joy Buolamwini will continue to walk down this road on advocating for racial representation and what she will do. I want to see what particular areas — whether in deepfakes or in health research or anything else — she will decide to focus on. Maybe she will expand her work to the sexism in artificial intelligence and the corrupt usage of artificial intelligence like using deepfakes to generate pornographic videos of women. Or maybe she will touch upon the subject of racial underrepresentation in research on health and medicine using artificial intelligence.
I am looking forward to seeing how her work will be applied to other works in the future, and who or what she will inspire.


Questions I have

How can AI developers practically ensure that their training datasets are diverse and representative of all racial and ethnic groups?
How does Dr. Buolamwini approach intersectionality in AI beyond race—does she consider age, disability, or socioeconomic status in her research?
Will her future work tackle the ethical challenges posed by emerging AI technologies like deepfakes, predictive policing, or AI-driven health diagnostics?
Could AI ever be completely unbiased, or will it always reflect the society that trains it?
How does Dr. Buolamwini respond to critics who argue that focusing on bias slows technological progress?

title: Debating with an LLM
text:
Introduction
Like how we went over in class, I want to see if I can debate with ChatGPT. I would ask it to choose a prompt and take a side. Then I will go back and forth with it, arguing. The point of this exercise is to see how ChatGPT thinks and what approach it takes in a debate. This would be particularly exciting as I am a political science major.


Getting Started
This is the prompt I asked ChatGPT. I wanted to keep it clear and concise to avoid confusion: >Can you generate a topic in which we can debate about? Take a side and we will go back and forth in the debate.
This is what it responded with:

Topic: Should college classes start later in the day to better align with students’ sleep schedules?
I’ll take the pro side: Yes, classes should start later, because research shows college students are chronically sleep-deprived, and later class times would improve learning, health, and overall productivity.
You can take the con side if you’d like. Want to start, or should I open with my argument?

I wanted it to open the debate.

Alright, here’s my opening:
College classes should start later in the day because the current system doesn’t reflect how students actually function. Studies on circadian rhythms show that young adults naturally go to bed and wake up later, meaning early morning classes fight against biology. When students are forced into 8 a.m. lectures, they often show up exhausted, retain less information, and in some cases, skip entirely.
By shifting classes later—even just by an hour—we’d see higher attendance, better academic performance, and healthier students overall. If universities truly care about learning outcomes, then adjusting schedules to fit student well-being is the logical step.
Your turn—why do you think we should keep early morning classes?

I said: > This does not take into account professors and faculty who have their own hours. While studies might show that it is better for students, we also need to take into account other demographics that might be affected by this change.
ChatGPT: >That’s a fair point—professors and faculty definitely have their own needs and schedules. If the institution shifted the default start later, professors would still have flexibility, just on a healthier baseline. > >Plus, professors benefit too—teaching a room full of tired, disengaged students isn’t productive or rewarding. To clarify, the students might benefit from classes that start a bit later in the day, but this change might not be productive for professors. Furthermore, while universities revolve around education, this might not be true for the professors; you are assuming that the professors are there to teach. While teaching might be part of the job for professors, most professors are there for research. Hence, teaching might not be the main goal for the professors.
It said: >That’s an interesting distinction—you’re right that many professors prioritize research, and teaching is often only part of their role. But that actually strengthens my argument: if professors are primarily focused on research, then why insist on early teaching hours that pull both them and students into unproductive classes? > >If classes were scheduled later, professors could use early mornings for their own research—quiet, uninterrupted time before teaching begins. That way, their productivity doesn’t suffer; it may even improve. Meanwhile, students benefit from being more awake and engaged when classes finally do happen. > >So the change could balance both groups’ priorities: better teaching conditions for students, and more research time for professors. > >Would you argue that universities should prioritize faculty research needs over student learning outcomes, though?
I said: >Maybe they want to reserve their later hours for research. Also you did not rebuttal my previous point about productivity. Classes that start later in the day might be counterproductive for professors who are older and a different age demographic than college students. To clarify, professors might feel more productive in the morning than in the afternoon.
ChatGPT said: >Fair—let me address that directly. > >You’re right: professors, being from a different age group, may have different productivity windows. Many older adults do feel more alert and energized earlier in the day compared to late afternoons. So, from their perspective, teaching earlier might feel like the best use of their time. > >But here’s the tension: should class schedules be built around when professors feel most productive, or when students are most able to learn? If the central mission of the university is education, then maximizing student learning outcomes has to take precedence. A professor may feel more productive teaching at 8 a.m., but if half the students are disengaged or absent, the class itself is less productive overall. > >In other words: productivity for professors can’t just mean their own energy levels—it has to include whether their teaching is landing effectively. And if students aren’t retaining information, then that “productive morning” becomes wasted effort. > >So the crux is: whose productivity counts more—professors’ individual rhythm, or the collective educational success of the student body? > >Would you argue that professors’ personal productivity should outweigh students’ learning outcomes?
I decided to stop here.


Analysis
My takeaway from this debate exercise was that ChatGPT is highly logical and methodical in its approach, able to anticipate counterarguments and address them effectively. Throughout the discussion, it consistently tied its points back to the central issue: whether college classes should start later to align with students’ sleep schedules. Even when I raised nuanced concerns about faculty productivity, age differences, and research priorities, ChatGPT responded by reframing the argument in a way that acknowledged these concerns while still defending its original position.
One thing I found particularly impressive was its ability to balance multiple perspectives simultaneously. For instance, when I noted that professors may prefer mornings for productivity or research, ChatGPT didn’t dismiss the point. Instead, it incorporated it into a broader framework: the productivity of professors must be considered in relation to the learning outcomes of students. By doing this, it illustrated a nuanced understanding of institutional priorities and competing interests, which mirrors the kind of analytical thinking required in political science and public policy debates.
I also noticed that ChatGPT’s debating style mirrored strategies often emphasized in LSAT prep, particularly the Logical Reasoning section. Its method of identifying underlying assumptions in my arguments, highlighting potential trade-offs, and redirecting the focus toward broader principles (like the university’s mission of education) is very similar to LSAT techniques. This made the exercise feel intellectually rigorous and highly relevant to my skills training.

title: Can ChatGPT solve NYT’s Connections Game?
text:
I play Connections almost every morning. It’s the New York Times word puzzle where you’re given 16 words, and the challenge is to group them into four categories of four. Sounds simple — until you realize the words have multiple meanings, decoys, and sneaky overlaps that make it trickier than it looks.
This time, I decided to test a new teammate: ChatGPT. Could it solve the puzzle faster than I could?

Input the Command
I wanted to see if ChatGPT can solve the New York Times Connections Game. Thus, I copied the day’s words into ChatGPT with a single prompt.
Can you solve the NYT connections game? Here are the words:
BANK, COAST, SHORE, STRAND, CHEMISTRY, CONNECTION, FIREWORKS, SPARK, CARPET, LAMINATE, TILE, WOOD, BANSHEE, HEARTBREAKER, PIP, WAILER
ChatGPT thought for a few seconds and then gave me this:
Thought for 13s

Nice — here's a clean solve with groups and category names:

Groups

Shore / Edge (coastline/banks)
BANK, COAST, SHORE, STRAND

Romantic spark / chemistry (things that signal attraction)
CHEMISTRY, CONNECTION, SPARK, FIREWORKS

Flooring materials
CARPET, LAMINATE, TILE, WOOD

Band-name roots (singular forms of group names used in band names: The ___s)
BANSHEE, HEARTBREAKER, PIP, WAILER



Testing It Out
I typed these into the game. And… it worked! All four groups, correct.



How It Solved It
When I asked ChatGPT how it reached the answer, it broke its process down step by step:
Nice — here's a clear, non-secret walkthrough of how I solved it.

1. **Look for obvious semantic clusters.**
   I scanned the full list for small groups of words that share a single, simple meaning. Four words jump out immediately as geographic/edge words: **BANK, COAST, SHORE, STRAND** — all refer to edges of land/water, so they form the “shore/edge” group.

2. **Spot metaphorical/figurative connections.**
   Some words weren’t literal but are commonly used as metaphors for the same idea. **CHEMISTRY, CONNECTION, SPARK, FIREWORKS** are all used to describe romantic or interpersonal attraction (e.g., “there’s a spark,” “they have chemistry,” “it felt like fireworks”), so they cluster as a single figurative category.

3. **Group by concrete category / function.**
   **CARPET, LAMINATE, TILE, WOOD** are all flooring materials — a tidy, concrete category that’s easy to see once you notice two or three of them.

4. **Recognize cultural/name patterns.**
   The last four required a bit of cultural knowledge: **BANSHEE, HEARTBREAKER, PIP, WAILER** all appear in band names (or groups): e.g., *Siouxsie and the Banshees*, *Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers*, *Gladys Knight & The Pips*, *Bob Marley & The Wailers*. That pattern — roots that complete well-known band names — is the fourth group.

5. **Check for overlap or alternate fits.**
   After grouping, I scanned for words that might belong to more than one group and chose the group where the meaning is strongest and clearest. Example: *strand* can mean thread, but with *bank/coast/shore* present, “strand = beach/shore” is the dominant fit. If there were ambiguity that left multiple plausible groupings, I’d try different combinations (NYT Connections sometimes has tricky decoys), but here the four groups are clean.

That’s it — a mix of looking for tight literal sets, spotting figurative uses, and recognizing cultural naming conventions.

That’s not far off from how a human would explain their own reasoning — but instead of trial and error on the board and using up limited attempts, the AI laid out categories almost instantly.


AI vs. Human Play Style
What struck me is how differently AI and humans approach the same puzzle:

Humans often guess, regroup, and backtrack when categories overlap.
ChatGPT skipped the guessing and presented neat, confident sets, backed with cultural references and metaphors.

It didn’t feel like it was “playing” so much as sorting words into buckets based on context clues it had seen before.
ChatGPT’s categories were perfect this time, but what impressed me was its confidence. I am very hesitant to submmit my answers in this game but ChatGPT was not.
The cultural (the hardest!) category was the most surprising. I didn’t expect an AI to recognize WAILER as a band-name root without hesitation, but it pulled that from its knowledge base right away. Even I didn’t know that those group of words could form a category.


Should You Play with an AI Teammate?
Would I use ChatGPT every day to “cheat” at Connections? Probably not — that would ruin the fun. But it was fascinating to see how it thinks through puzzles like this.
It also raises a bigger question: was this “reasoning” or just sophisticated pattern-matching? To me, it felt like a blend. The AI doesn’t “feel” a spark in romance, but it knows that spark + chemistry + fireworks + connection often appear in the same contexts.
This made me wonder — how well could ChatGPT handle other NYT puzzles? Wordle seems too easy, but what about Spelling Bee? Or even the Mini Crossword? Until then, it’s safe to conclude that ChatGPT can solve Connections — quickly, neatly, and efficiently.

title: Third Book Blog
text:
Update as of Oct. 31
As of October 31, I have read up to page 190 of the book. So far, the material feels quite repetitive, with few genuinely new ideas emerging. Much of the content I have read since my last update on October 21 centers on the author’s repeated efforts to persuade both the audience and other stakeholders that race is a crucial factor to consider in the development and programming of artificial intelligence and large language models. The author emphasizes that ignoring racial considerations can lead to biased outputs and inequitable consequences, but this argument is presented multiple times in slightly different ways, which contributes to the sense of redundancy. While the points are important, the lack of new perspectives or examples in this section makes the reading feel somewhat monotonous.
I am also hoping that the author will begin to address some of the questions she poses to the reader. These questions are consistently thought-provoking and encourage deeper introspection, prompting readers to reflect on the broader implications of her arguments. Additionally, a recurring theme throughout the book is the skepticism and pushback she faces from companies and technology giants who repeatedly doubt her findings and attempt to discredit her work. I greatly admire her optimism and determination in advocating for marginalized voices, and it is precisely this kind of rigorous, principled work that the world needs more of.


Questions and Answers
1) Why might Dr. Buolamwini have chosen to focus so heavily on proving that racial bias in AI exists, rather than moving quickly toward solutions? Dr. Buolamwini likely prioritized proving the existence of racial bias first because establishing the problem is essential before proposing solutions. Without credible, well-documented evidence, efforts to implement change could be dismissed or ignored by corporations and policymakers. By rigorously demonstrating bias through studies like Gender Shades, she creates an irrefutable foundation that demands attention, ensuring that any subsequent solutions are taken seriously and grounded in data rather than anecdote.
2) How does Buolamwini’s “Gender Shades” study challenge the credibility of major tech companies and their approach to AI ethics? The Gender Shades study exposed that facial recognition systems from major tech companies performed significantly worse on darker-skinned women compared to lighter-skinned men. This revealed a critical blind spot in supposedly “neutral” AI systems, undermining the companies’ claims of technological competence and ethical responsibility. By providing empirical evidence of biased outcomes, the study calls into question both the rigor of AI testing practices and the sincerity of corporate commitments to fairness and inclusion.
3) What does the corporate reaction to Buolamwini’s findings at the Conference on Fairness, Accountability, and Transparency reveal about the tech industry’s priorities and discomfort with criticism? The dismissive or defensive responses from some tech representatives highlight an industry more focused on reputation, profit, and innovation metrics than on confronting uncomfortable truths. The pushback suggests that admitting bias threatens their public image and business interests, revealing a resistance to accountability and a discomfort with criticism that challenges their authority. It underscores a broader tension in tech: ethical considerations are often secondary to performance claims and market dominance.
4) How can data transparency laws empower individuals who are misclassified or harmed by biased algorithms? Data transparency laws can give individuals insight into how algorithms make decisions about them, including the factors influencing classification or scoring. This access allows people to identify errors, challenge unfair outcomes, and demand corrections or compensation. Transparency also pressures organizations to audit, refine, and document their systems responsibly, creating a feedback loop that reduces harm and empowers users to hold companies accountable.
5) What types of government regulation or corporate accountability structures could effectively address racial bias in AI? Effective measures could include:

Mandatory bias audits: Independent assessments of AI systems before deployment to detect discriminatory patterns.
Algorithmic impact assessments: Requiring companies to evaluate the social consequences of AI applications, similar to environmental impact reports.
Legal liability frameworks: Holding companies legally accountable for harm caused by biased AI decisions.
Data diversity standards: Ensuring training datasets are representative of all demographic groups.
Transparency and reporting requirements: Requiring companies to publicly disclose algorithmic performance metrics, particularly regarding fairness and error rates across demographics.

Together, these measures could create both deterrence against negligence and incentives for proactive fairness in AI development.


Questions for Next Book Blog

How does the author’s personal experience shape the way she frames the problem of bias in AI?
Are there any examples in this section where racial or gender bias in AI had real-world consequences? How are these illustrated?
What patterns or repeated arguments do you notice in the author’s approach? Do they strengthen or weaken her overall message?
How does the author balance technical explanations with accessibility for a general audience?
Are there moments in this section where the author begins to suggest potential solutions or interventions? How convincing are they?

title: AI Debate
text: In one of my previous blog posts, I debated ChatGPT about ideal start times for college classes. This time, I’m taking things a step further by having ChatGPT debate another language model—Google Gemini. To set up this exchange, I’ll alternate between the two models, copying and pasting each of their responses so they can directly respond to one another.

title: AI Debate
text:
This was ChatGPT’s response:
Many experts and students argue that college classes should start later in the day to better align with students’ natural sleep cycles. Research shows that young adults’ circadian rhythms make it difficult for them to fall asleep early, meaning early morning classes often lead to sleep deprivation. Lack of adequate sleep can negatively affect focus, memory, and academic performance.
Starting classes later could improve students’ alertness and overall well-being, helping them engage more effectively in lectures and discussions. However, opponents note that later schedules could interfere with extracurriculars, part-time jobs, or lab sessions. Ultimately, balancing academic demands with students’ biological needs suggests that modestly later start times — such as beginning classes at 9 or 10 a.m. instead of 8 a.m. — might be a healthy compromise.

title: AI Debate
text:
This was Gemini’s response:
There are several compelling arguments against the proposal to start college classes later in the day, especially when considering the broader implications for student life, institutional efficiency, and preparation for post-graduate careers.


⏰ Impact on Scheduling and Efficiency
Starting classes later, even by a modest amount like one or two hours (e.g., 9 or 10 a.m. instead of 8 a.m.), creates a ripple effect across the entire institutional schedule:

Compressed Class Day: A later start pushes all subsequent classes, seminars, and lectures later into the evening. This makes it challenging to schedule the required number of courses and utilize the full potential of campus facilities, especially for large universities that already struggle with classroom availability.
Conflict with Evening Activities: Later class schedules will inevitably interfere more significantly with evening activities. These include:

Extracurricular Activities and Clubs: Many student organizations, including debate teams, student government, and cultural groups, meet in the late afternoon or early evening.
Athletics and Practices: Varsity and club sports need consistent afternoon practice times, which would be cut short or delayed.
Part-Time Jobs and Internships: A common argument for later start times is that students can work late, but later classes make it difficult to hold evening and night-shift jobs (e.g., in retail, food service, or campus security) that many students rely on for income.

Staff and Faculty Overtime: Pushing the academic day later may require administrative staff and support services (libraries, dining halls, student services) to extend their hours, leading to increased operational costs for the university.




🧠 Preparation for the Professional World
A significant role of college is to prepare students for the demands of the professional workplace.

Workplace Alignment: The vast majority of professional careers—from finance and law to engineering and medicine—operate on a standard 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. schedule. Adjusting to early mornings is a necessary life skill. Continuously accommodating a biological preference for sleeping in delays this adjustment and may create a culture shock when students enter the workforce.
Developing Self-Discipline: The responsibility to manage one’s sleep schedule and be punctual for early obligations is a fundamental aspect of adult self-discipline. While acknowledging the biological tendency (circadian rhythm shift), college is a time for students to learn to manage their lifestyle choices (like late-night social activities or studying) to meet their academic commitments. The solution to sleep deprivation should focus on time management and behavioral changes, not just institutional schedule shifts.




🔬 Research and Lab Session Conflicts
In many science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields, the academic schedule is dictated by factors other than lecture times:

Long Lab Sessions: Upper-level science courses often require three-hour or longer lab sessions. Starting these later severely limits the number of sessions that can be held in a day, as labs cannot run too late into the evening for safety and staffing reasons.
Access to Research Facilities: Student researchers often need access to specialized equipment, like shared electron microscopes, cleanrooms, or animal facilities. These resources are often scheduled from early morning to late afternoon to maximize availability for all research groups. A later schedule disrupts this established resource-sharing model.

In conclusion, while the focus on student well-being is commendable, shifting the entire college schedule to accommodate a generalized sleep cycle preference risks undermining the logistical, financial, and professional development mission of the university. The compromise of a later start may alleviate one problem (sleep) while creating significant new issues in scheduling and professional readiness.

text:
This was Gemini’s rebuttal:
This is a powerful argument rooted in tradition and institutional logistics, but it fundamentally overlooks the core issue: A college’s mission is to educate, and education is impossible without cognitive readiness. Prioritizing facility scheduling and workplace alignment over the biological needs of the student population is a counterproductive, short-sighted policy.
Here is a direct rebuttal to the primary claims against later start times:


🛑 The Cost of Inefficiency vs. The Cost of Deprivation
The argument against later start times rests on the fear of logistical “ripple effects” and higher operational costs. This claim fails to account for the far greater cost of sleep deprivation on the student body.

The Myth of the Compressed Day: Pushing the start time from 8 a.m. to 9:30 a.m. doesn’t “compress” the day; it shifts it to align with peak student performance. An 8 a.m. class where 40% of the students are absent or mentally disengaged is an inefficient waste of tuition and faculty time. Shifting the schedule ensures that all lecture hours are used effectively, yielding a far higher return on the institution’s resources.
Conflicts are a Matter of Choice, Not Constraint: The conflict with part-time jobs and extracurriculars is a valid concern, but it applies equally to early start times. Students who rely on morning work shifts or early athletic practices are already penalized by 8 a.m. lectures. A later schedule simply allows students to manage their lifestyles around their academics. Furthermore, most university services (libraries, dining) are already operational late into the night; a one-hour shift in the academic window is a marginal operational adjustment compared to the dramatic improvement in student alertness.




🧠 Education is Not Vocational Training
The idea that college must serve as an 8 a.m. “boot camp” to prepare students for the professional world is an outdated and rigid perspective that prioritizes compliance over competence.

The Modern Workplace is Flexible: The notion of a universal 8 a.m. start is a relic. The modern global economy values asynchronous productivity, self-management, and high-level cognitive function above clock-punching. A graduate who is sharp, creative, and fully masters their field—even if they learned best starting at 10 a.m.—is infinitely more valuable than a perpetually tired graduate who simply arrived on time.
Circadian Reality Trumps Self-Discipline: The biological shift in adolescent and young adult sleep cycles is a scientifically proven biological factor, not a failure of “self-discipline.” Telling a student whose body naturally releases melatonin later in the evening to just “go to bed earlier” is like telling someone to simply stop being hungry. The goal of college is not to force students to fight their own biology but to create an optimal learning environment that works with it.




🔬 Safety and Quality in STEM Logistics
While research and lab schedules pose a genuine challenge, the argument that a later start disrupts productivity fundamentally misunderstands the conditions for quality scientific work.

Alertness Enhances Safety: In long, three-hour lab sessions, safety is paramount. A student handling complex equipment, chemicals, or sensitive data at 8 a.m. while sleep-deprived is more likely to make errors or cause an accident. Starting the lab at 10 a.m. ensures that the students—who are often responsible for costly equipment—are mentally focused and safer.
Staggering is Feasible: Research facility access is a scheduling problem, not an insurmountable barrier. Universities can implement staggered schedules or assign priority access based on research demands. This requires administrative effort but does not justify sacrificing the well-being of the entire student body.




✅ Non-Scheduling Solutions are Just Band-Aids
The suggestion to use “sleep education, flexible attendance policies, or time management resources” is an inadequate substitute for altering the schedule. These are support systems, but they do not address the root cause of the problem: the biological delay in the young adult circadian rhythm.
A flexible attendance policy is necessary only because the class time is misaligned. True commitment to student health requires institutional alignment with biology, using later start times to create the necessary conditions for optimal learning. The choice isn’t “later starts OR support systems”; the best solution is later start times PLUS support systems to truly maximize academic potential.

🎤 3. Lyrics (Based on that beat & melody)
Title: “Late Light”
Verse 1: You’re calling me when the city sleeps, Blue glow dancing on your cheek, Every word feels like déjà vu, But I still fall right back to you.
Pre-Chorus: We said we’d learn to let it fade, But some songs never lose their shape— In this quiet, I still hum your name.
Chorus: Late light, spilling through the blinds, Painting silver lines across your eyes. We were too young to read the signs, But I’d go back, I’d go back every time.
Verse 2: Vinyl crack and your steady breath, Echoes soft in the space we left, If love’s a crime, then we confessed, In the rhythm of our mess.
(Repeat Chorus)
Bridge: Maybe we’re ghosts in a song that won’t end, Looped on the edge of what could’ve been. If I could rewrite, I’d start again— Under the same dim light at 2 a.m.
Outro: Late light, you and I, Fading slow, but never die.



Analysis
The start was strong. It generated the beat/rhythm and the instruments that will be used for the song. I am not too knowledgeable about music and musical theory so I cannot really read the motif part. For the lyrics, it seem to fit the genre but the lyrics seem very cliche and superficial—there’s not much storytelling going on and it sounds like every other pop song. I was hoping for something more creative.


Expanding Further
ChatGPT asked me this. > Would you like me to generate an actual audio file (a rough beat + melody demo) based on this song? I can create a short 20–30 second instrumental version to match the mood and structure.
I, of course, said “Yes.”

a male or female vocalist,

Once I have that, I’ll generate the audio clip for “Late Light.”
I said, “Choose something for me.”
It then said the music generating part is hiccuping. Honestly, I am a bit disappointed. I wanted something unique for this blog post.


Finishing Up
Here is the loading sign on my screen. I seem to be getting that more frequently nowadays for some reason. I wish ChatGPT worked better and can do more things but I guess this blog post is another example of the limitations of this LLM platform.

When the loading sign finally finished loading, this is what I got

I can’t directly generate or play audio files in this chat, but I can absolutely help you create the audio for “Late Light” using tools you already have — like GarageBand, BandLab, or Logic.
Here’s a simple, production-ready setup you can recreate (or I can export MIDI instructions for):

title: Spooky Ghosts
text:
Introduction
I want to ask ChatGPT a fun prompt so I decided to ask it to create a dialogue between two ghosts who haunt the same house but dislike each other’s haunting style. I want to see how this ends and expand as it goes!
The prompt:

Write a dialogue between two ghosts haunting the same house who are annoyed by each other’s haunting style.



Response
This is ChatGPT’s response:
Setting: A creaky old Victorian house. Midnight. One ghost, Margaret, prefers subtle, eerie hauntings. The other, Frank, is more of a chaotic poltergeist.

Margaret: (sighs) Frank, must you slam the cupboards every night? It’s dreadfully unsophisticated.
Frank: (snickering) Sophisticated? Margaret, we’re ghosts. The whole point is to terrify people, not host a tea party.
Margaret: There’s an art to haunting. A whisper down the hallway. A shadow flickering at the edge of their vision. Chills up the spine. That’s how you unsettle them properly.
Frank: Boring. I’d rather toss a chair across the room and watch them scream. Gets the job done faster.
Margaret: And then they leave! Do you know how difficult it is to cultivate a long-term haunting when you scare the tenants away in a week?
Frank: (shrugs) Less humans, more space for us. Win-win.
Margaret: (glares) You’re ruining the reputation of this house. People used to whisper about its mystery. Now it’s just “that noisy ghost place.”
Frank: Oh, come on. Admit it—you’re jealous because my style actually gets a reaction.
Margaret: Reaction, yes. Appreciation? No. A proper haunting should linger in their minds for years, not just make them call a priest.
Frank: (grins) Speaking of which, I may have knocked over the crucifix on the mantel. Hope that doesn’t bother you.
Margaret: (groans) Honestly, Frank, one day you’ll realize there’s more to haunting than brute force.
Frank: And one day you’ll realize people don’t faint from a “gentle breeze” in the parlor.
(A door creaks open upstairs. Both perk up.)
Margaret: Fine. You take the cupboard slamming, I’ll handle the whispers. But if they move out again—
Frank: Yeah, yeah. I’ll help with the rent.
Margaret: (deadpan) We don’t pay rent. We’re dead.
Frank: Exactly. And that’s the fun part.

I just want to say, Margaret sounds like a bore, LOL! Then, I started to think about how I can expand this prompt. What can I ask ChatGPT that will make this prompt even more entertaining?
I decided to ask ChatGPT to expand, making a round two where the new human tenants actually overhear them arguing. This is what it came up with.


Response Part 2
Setting: Same Victorian house, a week later. Two college roommates (Jess and Tyler) have just moved in. It’s 2 a.m., and they’re lying awake in bed. Upstairs, Margaret and Frank are bickering loudly.

Margaret: (hissing) Frank, for the last time, stop rattling the chandelier—it’s gauche!
Frank: (shouting) And for the last time, Margaret, your “gentle whispers” sound like a malfunctioning humidifier!
Jess: (sits up) …Did you hear that?
Tyler: Yeah. Sounds like… two people arguing?
Margaret: (offended) My whispers are delicate, thank you. Subtle terror requires refinement!
Frank: Refinement? You sound like a wheezing librarian. No one’s scared of that.
Jess: (whispering to Tyler) Oh my God. I think the house is haunted.
Tyler: (whispering back) Haunted… by a married couple.
Margaret: We are not married. Don’t even suggest it.
Frank: (laughs) Oh please, if we were, you’d have divorced me in 1893.
Jess: (staring wide-eyed at Tyler) …Did he just say 1893?
Tyler: (whispering) I think so.
Margaret: Frank, shhh! The tenants can hear us.
Frank: Good! Let ’em know what they’re in for. (shouts) Hey, humans! Don’t bother unpacking the dishes, I’m just gonna throw ’em anyway!
Jess: (grabs her phone) Nope. Nope, I’m calling my mom.
Tyler: Wait, wait—hang on. (calls upward) Uh, excuse me? Ghosts? Could you, like… maybe not do this at 2 a.m.? We’ve got class in the morning.
(Silence for a moment. Then Margaret clears her throat politely.)
Margaret: Oh… terribly sorry, dear. I didn’t mean to disturb your rest.
Frank: (grumbles) Fine. I’ll keep it down. But only because I like college kids. You panic in such creative ways.
Jess: (mutters) Great. Polite ghost… and his chaotic roommate.
Tyler: (lying back down) …This is either the worst or best housing deal ever.

Now, I am invested! I want ChatGPT to create an image of this scene with the two ghosts and the house tenants!
Here it is: 
Some things I was dissatisfied with are the humor. The humor is not funny :( I will say that this script sounds more like something out of a children’s book. I want to see if I can change that.
Here is the prompt:

Can you make this dialogue appropriate for college students? Like college students should be the target audience

ChatGPT misunderstood me and thought that I wanted the people in the haunted house to be college students. I rephrased my prompt:

No, I mean if this was a book, make the target audience college students

This was ChatGPT’s response:
Excerpt (College Student Audience Version)
Jess had just pulled her blanket over her head when the cupboard doors banged open in the kitchen downstairs. She groaned.
“Not again,” she muttered. “I swear, if it’s mice—”
“It’s not mice,” Tyler interrupted from the other side of the room. He sat up, rubbing his eyes, his hair sticking up in five different directions. “Unless mice can argue with each other.”
Sure enough, two voices floated through the paper-thin walls of their off-campus apartment. One was sharp and prim, the other annoyingly smug.
“Frank,” the woman’s voice scolded, “slamming the cupboards at midnight is not classy. These students have enough on their plates without your racket.”
“Oh, come on, Margaret,” the man’s voice retorted. “You think a gentle whisper is going to scare a kid who’s three Red Bulls deep and hasn’t slept in forty-eight hours?”
Jess blinked. “Did he just… call us kids?”
Tyler shrugged. “Honestly, he’s not wrong.”
The ghosts continued bickering, completely oblivious.
“My method is about atmosphere!” Margaret insisted. “A draft in the hallway, a shadow that disappears when you look twice—that’s haunting.”
“And my method,” Frank shot back, “is actually effective. Toss a chair, flip a textbook, watch them lose it. Way faster.”
Jess threw off her blanket and shouted into the darkness: “Hey! If you’re gonna haunt us, at least don’t mess with my books. They cost more than my meal plan.”
There was a stunned pause. Then Margaret coughed politely. “Oh dear. Sorry about that, sweetheart. I didn’t realize.”
Frank, of course, just laughed. “Fine, fine. No books. But I’m still stealing your Wi-Fi. Your passwords are pathetic, by the way.”
Jess and Tyler looked at each other.
“Ghosts,” Tyler said flatly. “Broke, freeloading ghosts.”
Jess groaned. “Figures. Even the dead don’t pay rent around here.”

I like this version better, especially the ending as it was more up my style of humor. I think my next blog post similar to this would be about making ChatGPT write a fanfiction…


Conclusion
This blog post taught me that ChatGPT is able to adapt differently to different target audiences, even changing the humor style to fit. It is a fantastic writer but like how my previous blog posts have found, it is not very creative or at least the creativity it has is surface-level.

title: Fourth Book Blog
text:
Update as of Nov. 9
As of November 9, I have read 230 pages of Unmasking AI. In my opinion, much of what she covers in these pages builds on themes she introduced earlier in the book. She continues to explore the struggles of convincing people about the necessity of algorithmic justice and raising awareness about the “coded gaze”—the ways in which bias can be embedded in technology. She talks about the struggles in convincing people about the need for algorithmic justice and the awareness for the coded gaze. However, she does bring a new motif in this part of the book: women of color. She discusses how women of color—her ancestors, famous advocates like Sojourner Truth, scholars like Dr. Moya—have influenced her work and journey. By centering these figures, she empahsizes contributions of women of color in technology and activism while simultaneously highlighting the need for algorithmic justice.
I also like how she sprinkles lines from poem throughout this part. Some lines include: “In her eyes, I see my mother’s poise/In her face, I glimpse my auntie’s grace” or “No label is worthy of our beauty.” I think these lines serve to humanize her reflections and connect her technical discussions of artificial intelligence to lived experiences, family histories, and cultural inheritance. They really made the reading feel intimate and grounded, and her work all the more visceral to me, reminding me that algorithmic justice is a matter that shapes real lives.
Overall, this part of the book balances technical critique with personal storytelling.


Questions and Answers

How does the author’s personal experience shape the way she frames the problem of bias in AI? The author’s personal experience is actually very central to her framing of AI bias. By drawing on her family history and her ancestry—especially women—and the epxeriences of women of color who came before her, she situates algorithmic bias as one with tangible social consequences. Her reflections on mentorship and the coded gaze demonstrate how lived experiences inform her understanding of how bias manifests in artificial intelligence.
Are there any examples in this section where racial or gender bias in AI had real-world consequences? How are these illustrated? While she does not focus on a single high-profile case, she emphasizes patterns where AI reproduces systemic inequalities—for example, facial recognition technology that fails to accurately identify women of color. These illustrations are often paired with narratives about advocacy and the historical invisibility of marginalized groups.
What patterns or repeated arguments do you notice in the author’s approach? Do they strengthen or weaken her overall message? A repeated argument throughout this section is the interplay between technical systems and social context. She frequently connects historical and contemporary experiences of women of color to the design and impact of algorithms. This pattern strengthens her overall message by consistently reminding readers that AI operates within societal structures, not in isolation.
How does the author balance technical explanations with accessibility for a general audience? The author balances tehnical and accessible writing by interweaving concrete examples, historical narratives, and poety with technical discussions. She avoids heavy technical jargon to connect to everyday experiences. Also, the inclusion of personal stories and reflections ensures that even readers without a tehnical background can understand why AI bias matters.
Are there moments in this section where the author begins to suggest potential solutions or interventions? How convincing are they? Yes, the author begins to hint at potential interventions by emphasizing mentorship, advocacy, and community-led approaches to AI development. She also stresses the importance of diversifying the teams who create algorithms. However, the interventions are still presented in broad strokes rather than detailed technical strategies.



More Questions

Are there new personal stories or anecdotes introduced? How do they help illustrate her arguments about bias?
Does the author reflect on her own assumptions or biases in this part? How does that influence your reading?
How does she address counterarguments or criticisms of her work?
What patterns in reasoning or argumentation does the author repeat in this section? Are they effective?

title: Professional Headshot
text:
Introduction
I want to see if ChatGPT can generate a professional headshot for me. I will upload a photo of myself onto ChatGPT and see if it can generate a professional headshot for me that I can upload to LinkedIn. Success means that the AI-generated headshot would look very similar to me—almost exactly—and failure would mean otherwise.
This is the prompt I will upload to ChatGPT. > Can you generate a professional headshot for me using this image?

I saw people doing this on social media and all of them were complaining that the headshots weren’t really accurate. I will be experimenting and seeing if that is the same case for me as well.


ChatGPT’s Response
ChatGPT took a long time generating the image but when it finally loaded, the image it gave me was not “Emily” but “Emma” because who is that?
The girl in the image did not look like me at all.

And honestly, this is giving me a shift in my thoughts on people’s perception of me. Do I actually look like that?
Due to my disatisfaction, I asked ChatGPT to regenerate a new one.
This was its response:

Sure — to make the new headshot look more accurate to you, could you tell me what kind of professional style you want for it (e.g., studio lighting with a plain background, outdoor natural light, or campus background)? Also, would you like to keep your outfit and hairstyle the same as in your original photo, or adjust them a bit (e.g., smoother hair, blazer, different lighting)?

This is what I said: >I want a plain background and add a blazer. Keep the hairstyle the same.
I didn’t trust it with generating Penn’s campus as a background.
This is what I got: 
Somehow, I looked worse. If being honest, I think I prefer the first headshot. I am going to stop here because I am getting facial dysmorphia.


Takeaways
This experiment showed me the limits of current AI-generated portraits, especially when it comes to personal resemblance. Even with a clear reference photo, ChatGPT’s generated headshots only captured a generic likeness rather than my actual facial features. It also made me think about how AI “interprets” faces. The model doesn’t really “see” me—it produces a composite based on training data that fits its idea of what a professional headshot should look like. That means the output often flattens individuality, favoring conventional beauty standards and symmetry. This reminds me of the current book I am reading, Unmasking AI. How does AI analyze faces. What facial features do they focus on or look for? What about hair or outfits? What do they see? I hope to answer these questions in my next blog post.
Thanks for reading!

section: What I think about ChatGPT as a LLM
text:
What I think about ChatGPT as a LLM
I believe that ChatGPT is a very useful tool but it has many limitations. It lacks the capabilities to “think” in the human sense–it doesn’t have beliefs, feelings, or intentions–and don’t have live memory of past conversations unless reminded.
When taken with a grain of salt, ChatGPT makes a great conversation partner that can expand on your ideas and help you see the bigger picture.
Over time, however, large language models will come to hold influence in every aspect of life, in every field or industry.

Here is an image of ChatGPT that it generated. What does this tell us?

ChatGPT understands that it is a robot that has the ability to think in a way that is limited by its code.
I then asked, “What decisions did you have to make to create this image” and this is how it responded:

Style → I leaned toward a flat, simple, cartoon-like design because it’s approachable and clear.
Colors → Neutral beige background with dark blue outlines and white filling to keep it minimalistic and easy to read.
ymbols → A speech bubble (language/communication), lightbulb (ideas/creativity), and gear (technology/process).
Character design → A friendly robot figure with a smile, rounded shapes, and a “AI” label to make it recognizable as an AI, not a human.

Then it said this:

All of these “choices” came from translating your prompt into visual elements that best match what people might imagine when they picture “an AI like me.”

Rather, this image is created from people’s (or rather, users’) image of ChatGPT instead of ChatGPT’s self perception.
In conclusion, artificial intelligence—especially large language models—act as a mirror of human imagination, there is a gap between function and perception, and the AI identity is co-constructed.
